The claim originated from a satirical we: Empire News, which clearly states that its content is intended for entertainment purposes only. This indicates that the claim is not based on real news.
The article from Empire News quotes the: Mario Dorcy, who supposedly claims that the restaurant has received government approval to serve human flesh. However, the satirical nature of the website casts doubt on the authenticity of this statement.
The same claim was found on other websit: Elite News Press and Desert Herald, as well as being shared by users on Facebook. This widespread dissemination of the claim adds to its visibility but does not provide evidence of its authenticity.
The American website Snopes: known for fact-checking, has previously debunked this claim, further confirming that it is not based on reality.
